Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: High-throughput Single-molecule Studies of Replication Conflict and Restart.

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The genomes of all living organisms must complete two essential functions-DNA replication and transcription. Conflicts between the replication and transcription machineries are pervasive on DNA and can lead to catastrophic outcomes including structural damage to DNA and mutagenesis. The goal of this project is to examine at a molecular level how replication-transcription conflicts occur and are resolved. The exciting research topic of "molecular machines" will also be used to inspire students' interest in science at the early-education stage. As part of the institutional Freshman Research Initiative undergraduates with minimal laboratory experience will be trained in inquiry-based research using quantitative biochemical and biophysical methods. Graduate students and postdoctoral fellows will be trained in these interdisciplinary areas as well. Additionally, the PI will participate in projects aimed at exposing local under-resourced middle school students to research early in their education.

High-throughput single-molecule fluorescence imaging will be used to directly observe the intricate choreography of replication and transcription enzymes as they encounter each other on the same DNA molecule. The findings will shed light on replication-transcription conflicts, and help resolve the larger problem of how organisms replicate a genome that is crowded with many DNA-binding proteins. As part of the project, new methods for high-throughput single-molecule biology will be developed by combining elements of micro-fabrication and surface chemistry, and disseminated to the research community.

The project is co-funded by the Directorate for Biological Sciences (Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences: Genetic Mechanisms program and the Division of Emerging Frontiers) and by the Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences (Division of Chemistry: Chemistry of Life Sciences program).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objectives of this grant were to investigate how cells can replicate their genetic information on a crowded genome. A secondary objective was to develop ultrasensitive microscopes that can observe individual proteins as they go about their functions. All organisms assemble a multi-protein molecular machine called the replisome that opens the DNA duplex to copy its genetic information. However, the replisome must compete with many other cellular processes on the same DNA molecule, including transcription and DNA repair. One challenge in understanding how cells copy their genetic information is to understand how the replisome can accomplish its functions without crashing into all these other processes. Towards this goal, we developed new methods to image single proteins on DNA using a tool called DNA curtains. We developed new ways to assemble DNA molecules for microscopic imaging, and assembled reactions of the key protein components that stabilize the replisome. Our key discoveries included that RADX, a single-stranded DNA binding protein, can protect stalled replisomes from collapse by scrunching up the single-stranded DNA that is exposed during DNA replication. This prevents the repair protein RAD51 from loading on this DNA. We also showed how SSB, the bacterial single-stranded DNA binding protein, can also scrunch up single-stranded DNA. Additional insights included studies of the T4 gp32 protein, which is required for the replication of a virus that infects bacteria. We are continuing studies on replisome stability, especially in the context of a crowded genome.

A second major objective was to inspire students to study biochemistry with a focus on “molecular machines” at the college and middle school levels. We partnered with the Freshman Research Initiative to introduce a diverse cohort of students—especially those with minimal laboratory experience—to modern biochemical/biophysical methods via research-based training. These students followed their own research questions as they learned modern biochemistry. Many of them transitioned to independent research projects in my laboratory. This class was administered by a unique researcher-educator postdoctoral-level scientist at UT-Austin. In addition, I developed an upper-division undergraduate class that focuses on the replisome and other molecular machines to enhance and modernize the biochemistry curriculum at UT Austin. Lastly, I invited middle school students to “shadow a scientist” in my lab during the summer months. This program exposed the students to research early in their education and expanded their understanding of what scientists do at the bench.
